description:
Suillus fuscotomentosus is a species of mushroom in the genus Suillus, commonly known as the tomentose slippery jack or brown slippery jack. It is a mycorrhizal fungus, forming symbiotic relationships with the roots of certain coniferous trees, primarily pines (Pinus spp.).

The cap of S. fuscotomentosus is convex to flat, ranging from 5 to 15 cm in diameter, with a viscid, sticky surface that becomes less viscid as it matures. The cap color can vary from reddish-brown to dark brown, often with a tomentose (hairy) texture. The tubes and pores are initially whitish, turning yellowish or olive-brown with age. The stipe (stem) is 5 to 15 cm tall and 1 to 3 cm thick, with a ring-like annulus (skirt) that may disappear with age.

S. fuscotomentosus is primarily found in coniferous forests, particularly in association with pine trees, across North America and parts of Europe. It is considered edible, although its texture and flavor may not be preferred by some consumers. The species is known for its ecological importance in nutrient cycling and forest ecosystem dynamics through its mycorrhizal relationships with host trees.
